Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Development of New Oxidative Metal-Catalyzed C-N Bond Forming Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is devoted to the development of new methods for rapidly transforming inexpensive hydrocarbon starting materials into more complex biologically relevant compounds by direct introduction of nitrogen-containing functional groups. New metal-catalyzed oxidative amination reactions of carbon-carbon multiple bonds will be a significant focus of this work. Studies to understand the basic organic and organometallic mechanisms of the fundamental steps of these reactions will also be conducted.

With this award, the Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program is supporting the research of Professor Forrest Michael of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Washington. Professor Michael's research efforts revolve around the development of efficient methods for the formation of C-N bonds, specifically those that are tolerant of air, water, and complex functional groups, operate under mild conditions, and are highly stereoselective. The successful creation of a toolbox of C-N bond-forming reactions will provide more efficient access to biologically active small molecules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research funded by this CAREER Award resulted in the discovery of numerous new ways of transforming simple molecules into more complicated structures, especially those that contain nitrogen. New methods for making molecules that contain nitrogen are in high demand because of the useful biological properties that these molecules display. In the course of our research funded by this award, we have discovered new catalysts that efficiently form new carbon-nitrogen and carbon-carbon bonds to make key building blocks for biological applications. These catalysts were even found to be capable of activating molecules that are usually regarded as too inert to use as building blocks, like unactivated hydrocarbons. Careful study of these catalysts revealed the mechanism by which they exerted their unique control over the reactions and suggested ways to control and expand on this reactivity. Ultimately, research funded by this grant has changed the way synthetic chemists will think about making new carbon-nitrogen bonds.

In the course of this research, this grant has enabled the mentoring of 17 graduate students and 8 undergraduate students. All of these students had the opportunity to learn numerous useful laboratory techniques, as well as communication and presentation skills. Additionally, the PI has had the opportunity to educate and inspire gifted science students from across the country at the high school level at the Research Science Institute.


Last Modified: 06/02/2013
Modified by: Forrest Michael
